profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Wednesday April 24, 2019 at 03:01

did.unittitle: Currier & Ives Darktown Prints

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into two series: I. Published by Currier & Ives, 1880-1896. II. Restrikes, 1907.

bioghist.head: Currier & Ives
bioghist.p: Nathaniel Currier and James Merritt Ives, publishers of popular prints in New York between 1857 and 1907. After the firm disbanded, other publishers, including Joseph Koehler in New York and S. Lipschitz in London, acquired the company's lithographic stones and reprinted the images.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collections are processed to a variety of levels, depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived research value, the availability of staff, competing priorities, and whether or not further accruals are expected. The library attempts to provide a basic level of preservation and access for all collections, and does more extensive processing of higher priority collections as time and resources permit.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Carl Van Vechten, 1965; Gift of Julia Millhiser Gimbel, 1973. Other acquisitions are noted at the folder level.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Currier & Ives Darktown Prints is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Currier & Ives Darktown Prints. James Weldon Johnson Collection in the Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A collection of caricatures of African Americans published by the firm Currier & Ives as a series of "Darktown" comics. The drawings were made by artists associated with the firm, primarily John Cameron (1828-1906) and Thomas Worth (1834-1917). Also present are restrikes of "Darktown" images published later by Joseph Koehler in New York and S. Lipschitz & Son in London.

At the folder level, references are provided to the two standard Currier & Ives catalogues: Currier & Ives: a Catalogue Raisonné (Detroit: Gale Research, 1983) and Currier & Ives Prints: an Illustrated Checklist , by Frederick A. Conningham (New York: Crown Publishers, 1983).

did.unittitle: Published by Currier & Ives

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged in alphabetical order by title. However, companion or sequel prints were paired and foldered together, thus disrupting a strict alphabetical sequence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series I contains lithographs issued by the Currier & Ives firm.

The collection combines two groups of prints donated to the library separately by Carl Van Vechten and Julia Millhiser Gimbel, resulting in several instances of duplicate prints in the folders; these are noted at the folder level. Because the prints were hand colored, there are usually differences in coloring, and even variant title fonts in some cases. The donor's name is generally noted on the verso of each print, with Van Vechten's gifts bearing bookplates.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into two subseries: Published by Joseph Koehler, New York, and Published by S. Lipschitz, London.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series II contains eight prints issued by two firms that had acquired Currier & Ives lithographic stones after the company had closed operations. Joseph Koehler in New York published a numbered "Currier & Ives" series, while Lipschitz in London did not credit Currier & Ives.
